children.subject: hi i just finished taking 162! the textbook for the course is “Operating Systems: Principles and Practice” by Anderson and Dahlin btw, though i dont think people actually read it. at least for me, i wanted to read it/i thought it went pretty in depth when i did read it, but there is just no time during the semester :/

Also, any thoughts/advice on the following textbooks would be helpful: 

1) Head First C, 1st Edition by David Griffiths and Dawn Griffiths

2) 21st Century C, 2nd Edition by Ben Klemens

history.content:
As someone who just died on the 162 final, the big things are memory related, such as the stack and heap, virtual and physical memory, along with how to map between them with paging and the TLB, and caching. You should also be comfortable with C, especially structs and when to malloc/use pointers in heap vs using arrays on stack. Basic assembly does come up, but it is less about what the instruction actually is and more so the workflow of fetching and reading instructions. You could add in more with interrupts, IO devices, and more, but I'd prioritize C, then memory stuff, then everything else.



—————————————


I think the student perspective is super valuable but I figured I’d throw in the perspective of a TA for the class. Imo the biggest and most important prerequisite that people are missing is an understanding of C. There’s a cursory understanding of C that you should have which means that you should be comfortable writing C versions of programs that you are comfortable with writing in another language (I.e hw0 asks you to write a program which reads in a file and uses a linked list). The second level of understanding that you should ideally have is an understanding of the memory structure of a C programs (I.e where’s the heap, where’s the stack, when I allocate something where does it go?), how are things laid out in a struct,  pointers, etc. 


I think we pretty much teach virtual memory from scratch, though it’s super important and your life would be easier if you get a basic understanding of it from 61c.

As someone who just died on the 162 final, the big things are memory related, such as the stack and heap, virtual and physical memory, along with how to map between them with paging and the TLB, and caching. You should also be comfortable with C, especially structs and when to malloc/use pointers in heap vs using arrays on stack. Basic assembly does come up, but it is less about what the instruction actually is and more so the workflow of fetching and reading instructions. You could add in more with interrupts, IO devices, and more, but I'd prioritize C, then memory stuff, then everything else.
How should someone who scraped by 61C prepare for 162? What parts from 61C should I review specifically?
history.subject: CS 162 prep
